fields.descriptive_line: Theatrical ensemble of cloak, shoes and underdoublet, worn by Henry Irving as Philip II of Spain in Tennyson's 'Queen Mary' in 1876 at the Lyceum under Mrs Bateman's management.
fields.physical_description:
[shoe] Shoe covered in gold damask to match cloak (S.2759:3-2010). Decorated with appliqued section of dark gold silk to creating effect of 'slashing' at the toe. These oval 'slashes' are bound with dark gold braid. At the centre, above the instep, is an upstanding  roll of silk satin fabric, held in place by four tabs of silk damask. These tabs are decorated with narrow gold braid and false pearl beads. The heel of the shoe is also covered in gold damask. Scallops of narrow gold braid have also been used to decorate the upper edge of the back of the shoe. Lined in cream kid.
[shoe] Shoe covered in gold damask to match cloak (S.2759:3-2010). Decorated with appliqued section of dark gold silk to creating effect of 'slashing' at the toe. These oval 'slashes' are bound with dark gold braid. At the centre, above the instep, is an upstanding  roll of silk satin fabric, held in place by four tabs of silk damask. These tabs are decorated with narrow gold braid and false pearl beads. The heel of the shoe is also covered in gold damask. Scallops of narrow gold braid have also been used to decorate the upper edge of the back of the shoe. Lined in cream kid.
[cloak] Armhole cloak of old-gold damask, cut in Spanish style with stiffened collar, hanging sleeves ornamented with metal-tipped laces, and wide lapels of cream silk/cotton covered with lattice-work of gold braid and couched gold threadwork, and similar gold threadwork around hem and cuffs. Traces of makeup on left cream front.
[underdoublet] Sleeveless under-doublet of cream-coloured silk/cotton, covered with lattice-work of gold braid, and adorned with large imitation pearls and red glass jewels in gold metal settings surrounded by imitation diamonds. Centre opening fastened by seven self covered cream buttons with button holes (some wear). Small sewn-in ruffle at neck. Cotton back with double tape tie at waist.  Traces of dry make-up at breast and waist level.

[shoe] Length: 28.25 cm sole, Height: 3 cm Heel, Length: 11.5 cm From base of sole to highest point

[underdoublet] Length: 59 cm maximum, Width: 38 cm measured acrosst shoulders, Width: 48 cm measured across chest

fields.public_access_description:
Henry Irving (1838-1905) wore this costume as Philip II of Spain in Queen Mary by Alfred, Lord Tennyson (1809-1892).  Although Philip only appears in the third and fifth acts, Irving won unanimous critical praise for his characterisation of a cruelly malevolent individual.  Accounts of his performance also refer to the dramatic visual effect of costume and make-up.  

This costume was later worn by Irving in the role of Benedick in his 1882 production of Shakespeare’s Much Ado About Nothing.

Irving became a professional actor in 1856, and learned his trade in regional theatres until 1866, when he came to London.  He joined the Lyceum Theatre company under the management of H. L. Bateman in 1871, winning great acclaim that year for his psychologically developed characterisation of the guilt-ridden inn-keeper Mathias in Leopold Lewis’s melodrama The Bells.  He took on the responsibilities of ‘actor-manager’ in 1878 when he assumed the management of the Lyceum, and remained there until 1902, enjoying star status with his leading lady Ellen Terry (1847-1928).   Irving produced a diverse range of old and new plays at the Lyceum, including Shakespeare, historical drama, and literary adaptations.  His tireless work to elevate the status of the theatrical profession was rewarded in 1895 when he became the first actor ever to receive a knighthood for services to the Theatre.

Irving specialised in spectacularly staged productions with large casts of performers. He commissioned designers and composers to create appropriate scenery, costume and incidental music, played by a full orchestra.  Although electric lighting was available from the 1880s, Irving preferred the softer effects of gas, with lime light to focus attention at key points in the play.  Irving toured complete productions outside London, taking the full company, scenery and costumes throughout the United Kingdom and across the United States and Canada.   The development of the railway system made his the first generation able to achieve this level of touring productions.
fields.bibliography: Holmes, Martin. <u>Stage Costumes and Accessories in the London Museum</u>. London : HMSO, 1968. Catalogue entry 51; S.2760:3-2010 pl.IX.
fields.history_note:
[cloak] Museum of London note: 'Worn by Henry Irving as Philip of Spain, 1876 then as Benedick, 'Much Ado About Nothing' 1882. Note in London Museum register: 'Returned Sept 1960'.
[underdoublet] Museum of London note: 'This record was derived from the London Museum register; the object has not been traced. Note in London Museum register: Returned Sept 1960.'
